citations.narrative:
Facility representatives did not have disposition records for some animals that left the facility since the last inspection.
One coati, three guinea pigs, two raccoons and two rabbits are no longer present at the facility, and there are no records
of the details of their dispositions.
Records containing the required information for animals disposed of, or acquired for, use in regulated activities (including
those offspring born on premises) are necessary to accurately track animals to ensure their humane care and use. The
licensee must make and maintain records of the inventory, acquisition and disposition of all animals which fully and
correctly disclose the required information.

The enclosure housing two, adult female ring-tailed lemurs has accumulations of feces on the concrete floor inside all
three of the tires used as enrichment.
Accumulations of feces can attract pests and vermin and encourage soiling of the animals. The licensee must ensure that
surfaces with which non-human primates come in contact are spot-cleaned daily and sanitized in accordance with Section
3.84 of the Animal Welfare Act and Animal Welfare Regulations to prevent accumulation of excreta or disease hazards.

In the shelter structure inside the pen housing three adult coati, there is an accumulation of feces throughout the straw
bedding.
Accumulations of feces are malodorous, encourage soiling of the animals and attract pests and vermin. The licensee
shall remove excreta from primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent contamination of the animals contained
therein, to minimize disease hazards and reduce odors.
TO BE CORRECTED BY JUNE 7, 2023

In the commissary area, there is a drain gulley beneath the sink with an accumulation of food waste, and the
refrigerator/freezer unit used to store food for many of the animals at the facility has dried, pink material in the freezer and
food debris in numerous places.
In the enclosure housing two, adult male grey foxes, there are scraps of decomposing meat and a desiccated bird carcass
that were not removed after feeding. Some of the scraps were covered in flies. The facility representative did not know
how long the scraps and bird carcass had been inside the enclosure.
In the outdoor portion of the pen housing two, adult kinkajous, there are scraps of paper and duct tape on the ground.
Accumulations of food waste and uneaten scraps encourage microbial growth, contamination of food and can be a source
of disease-causing agents and odors when not removed after food prep and feedings. Trash or debris in enclosures can
cause entrapment, injury or illness due to ingestion.
Premises where facilities are located, including buildings and surrounding grounds, must be kept clean and in good repair
in order to protect the animals from injury or illness, and to facilitate the husbandry practices required in the regulations.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.75(b)  Repeat
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
Facility representatives did not have disposition records for some animals that left the facility since the last inspection.  
One coati, three guinea pigs, two raccoons and two rabbits are no longer present at the facility, and there are no records 
of the details of their dispositions.  
Records containing the required information for animals disposed of, or acquired for, use in regulated activities (including 
those offspring born on premises) are necessary to accurately track animals to ensure their humane care and use. The 
licensee must make and maintain records of the inventory, acquisition and disposition of all animals which fully and 
correctly disclose the required information. 
3.75(c)(3)  Repeat
   
Housing facilities, general. 
The enclosure housing two, adult female ring-tailed lemurs has accumulations of feces on the concrete floor inside all 
three of the tires used as enrichment.  
Accumulations of feces can attract pests and vermin and encourage soiling of the animals.  The licensee must ensure that 
surfaces with which non-human primates come in contact are spot-cleaned daily and sanitized in accordance with Section 
3.84 of the Animal Welfare Act and Animal Welfare Regulations to prevent accumulation of excreta or disease hazards.

3.131(a) 
   
Sanitation. 
In the shelter structure inside the pen housing three adult coati, there is an accumulation of feces throughout the straw 
bedding.   
Accumulations of feces are malodorous, encourage soiling of the animals and attract pests and vermin.  The licensee 
shall remove excreta from primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent contamination of the animals contained 
therein, to minimize disease hazards and reduce odors.  
TO BE CORRECTED BY JUNE 7, 2023 
3.131(c)  Repeat
   
Sanitation. 
In the commissary area, there is a drain gulley beneath the sink with an accumulation of food waste, and the 
refrigerator/freezer unit used to store food for many of the animals at the facility has dried, pink material in the freezer and 
food debris in numerous places.     
In the enclosure housing two, adult male grey foxes, there are scraps of decomposing meat and a desiccated bird carcass 
that were not removed after feeding.  Some of the scraps were covered in flies. The facility representative did not know 
how long the scraps and bird carcass had been inside the enclosure.  
In the outdoor portion of the pen housing two, adult kinkajous, there are scraps of paper and duct tape on the ground.  
Accumulations of food waste and uneaten scraps encourage microbial growth, contamination of food and can be a source 
of disease-causing agents and odors when not removed after food prep and feedings. Trash or debris in enclosures can 
cause entrapment, injury or illness due to ingestion.  
 Premises where facilities are located, including buildings and surrounding grounds, must be kept clean and in good repair 
in order to protect the animals from injury or illness, and to facilitate the husbandry practices required in the regulations.

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
